title: Species Composition Matrix Generation
text: DivInsight package can used repurpose historical occurrence taxon data order generate species composition matrix (SCM) specific time location. SCMs useful many ecological analyses.   Included package Colombia dataset, contains occurrence data taxon ‘Formicidae’ Family level 2000 2023. data queried Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) database using rgbif package.   row occurrence dataframe data observed individual. dataset many variables important ones functions DivInsight pertain taxa names, coordinate location, dates observations.

title: Species Composition Matrix Generation
text: occurrence data must first organised using clusterise_sites(). function clusters data date generates centered coordinates cluster. result, data clusters represent sites various dates locations.   pair longitude/latitude coordinates used centre point distance threshold set 50km. Therefore, occurrence data within 50km radius centre point clusterised. optional argument, group_radius, can use clusterise_sites() group sites based specified radius. However, argument used example; ’s group labels .   site_regroup() can used group clusterised sites using centred coordinates. radius group can specified using regroup_radius argument. method much faster running clusterise_sites() different parameters also useful experimenting different geographical ranges.   following example regroup radius set 1km. Therefore, sites farther 1km one another separated different groups. comparing site_group columns metadata regrouping can seen many different groups means sites farther 1km one another. Geographically makes sites suitable used create SCM.   Furthermore, since site data individual dates dates close one another terms time, many sites suitable combination create SCM. provide snapshot specific timeframe.

text: DivInsight package can used repurpose historical occurrence taxon data order generate diversity index values different dates locations.   Included package Colombia dataset, contains occurrence data taxon ‘Formicidae’ Family level 2000 2023. data queried Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) database using rgbif package.   row occurrence dataframe data observed individual. dataset many variables important ones functions DivInsight pertain taxa names, coordinate location, dates observations.

what: Clusterise data from an entire province
title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: Colombia dataset can subset province important function package clusterise_sites() can performed. function clusters data date generates centered coordinates cluster. result, data clusters represent sites various dates locations.     Furthermore, using optional argument group_radius, sites can grouped using specified radius metres.
code: Colombia_ValleCauca_dataframe <- subset(Colombia, stateProvince == "Valle del Cauca")   clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups <- clusterise_sites(      dataframe = Colombia_ValleCauca_dataframe,   cluster_min_length = 30,   group_radius = 20000    )

what: Generate diversity statistics for each site
title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: data ‘clusterised’ dataframe, row pertains site, can produced using generate_stats(). information includes dates observations, centred coordinates, diversity indices. indices included : Species Richness (S), Shannon Diversity (H), Simpson Diversity (D), Inverse Simpson (Dinv), Margalef’s Diversity (d), Pielou’s Evenness (J).

title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: Package functions can used easily plot diversity values time.
code: plot_sites_trend_H(   clusterised_object = clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups,   main_title = "Formicidae diversity in the Valle del Cauca province" )

title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: clusterised object contains two elements. first element contains clustered data second contains metadata. metadata centred coordinates dates site well group label.   group_radius argument used clusterise_sites() function label assigned group. using [[2]] index, metadata can viewed. column labeled site_group displays group labels.     Also, base R commands can used quickly see many sites group help us decide groups examine .

title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: , groups 2, 10, 7, 5 examined using filter_groups_by_number() store group’s data plot using plot_sites_scatter_H().
code: ValleCauca_2 <- filter_groups_by_number(clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups, 2) ValleCauca_10 <- filter_groups_by_number(clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups, 10) ValleCauca_7 <- filter_groups_by_number(clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups, 7) ValleCauca_5 <- filter_groups_by_number(clusterised_ValleCauca_20kmGroups, 5)  grid.arrange(   plot_sites_scatter_H(ValleCauca_2,  main = "Shannon's H at ValleCauca #2"),    plot_sites_scatter_H(ValleCauca_10, main = "Shannon's H at ValleCauca #10"),   ncol = 2 ) #> Warning: Use of `stats_dataframe$date` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `date` instead. #> Warning: Use of `stats_dataframe$H` is discouraged. #> ℹ Use `H` instead.  grid.arrange(   plot_sites_scatter_H(ValleCauca_7, main = "Shannon's H at ValleCauca #7"),   plot_sites_scatter_H(ValleCauca_5, main = "Shannon's H at ValleCauca #5"),   ncol = 2 )

title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: charts show varying patterns diversity available time frames important know changes taking place. map_start() can used create new map object map_add() can used add coordinate information.
code: # create a new map using group 1's coordinates Colombia_ValleCauca_map <-       map_start(          clusterised_object = ValleCauca_2,     site_name = "ValleCauca #2",     colour = "green"        )  # add group 5's coordinates to the map object  Colombia_ValleCauca_map <-      map_add(          existing_map = Colombia_ValleCauca_map,          clusterised_object = ValleCauca_10,     site_name = "ValleCauca #10",     colour = "purple"        )  # add group 6's coordinates to the map object Colombia_ValleCauca_map <-      map_add(          existing_map = Colombia_ValleCauca_map,          clusterised_object = ValleCauca_7,     site_name = "ValleCauca #7",     colour = "blue"        )  # add group 8's coordinates to the map object Colombia_ValleCauca_map <-      map_add(          existing_map = Colombia_ValleCauca_map,          clusterised_object = ValleCauca_5,     site_name = "ValleCauca #5",     colour = "red"        )   # view the map Colombia_ValleCauca_map

title: Diversity Statistics: Auto Clustering, Charting, and Mapping
text: subset data exact location pair longitude/latitude coordinates can used subset_by_coordinate_ref(). coordinate_reference argument mark centre location distance_threshold mark radius location metres.   function used argument value clusterise_sites() function get clusterised data two locations Colombia. radius location set 25km.
code: # clusterise coordinate reference location 1 clusterised_Colombia_CoordRef_1 <- clusterise_sites(      dataframe =          subset_by_coordinate_ref(       dataframe = Colombia,       coordinate_reference = c(-73.325377, 3.956982),       distance_threshold = 25000),      cluster_min_length = 30     )   # clusterise coordinate reference location 2 clusterised_Colombia_CoordRef_2 <- clusterise_sites(      dataframe =           subset_by_coordinate_ref(       dataframe = Colombia,       coordinate_reference = c(-71.889919, 4.470524),       distance_threshold = 25000),      cluster_min_length = 30     )   # view meta data for location 1 print(clusterised_Colombia_CoordRef_1[[2]]) #>    longitude latitude site_group       date #> 1  -73.46702 4.058576          1 2000-10-01 #> 2  -73.46702 4.058576          1 2000-10-06 #> 3  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2015-10-13 #> 4  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2015-11-19 #> 5  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2016-02-15 #> 6  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2016-02-24 #> 7  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2016-05-24 #> 8  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2016-06-13 #> 9  -73.47267 4.073333          1 2016-08-03 #> 10 -73.36824 4.083131          1 2022-11-09 #> 11 -73.38409 4.080567          1 2022-11-11 #> 12 -73.37865 4.091503          1 2022-11-14  # view meta data for location 2 print(clusterised_Colombia_CoordRef_2[[2]]) #>   longitude latitude site_group       date #> 1 -71.73596 4.340693          1 2012-05-01 #> 2 -71.81433 4.530222          1 2015-09-16 #> 3 -71.81433 4.530222          1 2015-10-13 #> 4 -71.81433 4.530222          1 2015-11-19 #> 5 -71.81433 4.530222          1 2016-02-15

code: # convert the GBIF object containing occurrence plant data from 2020 and 2019 # \donttest{  library(rgbif)   Cambodia_code <- isocodes[grep("Cambodia", isocodes$name), "code"]   Plant_taxonkey <- name_backbone("Plantae")$kingdomKey   plant_cambodia.gbif <- occ_search(    hasCoordinate = TRUE,    limit = 99990,    taxonKey = Plant_taxonkey,    year = c("2020", "2019"),    country = Cambodia_code  )   plant_cambodia.df <- gbif_to_dataframe(plant_cambodia.gbif)   head(plant_cambodia.df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 100 #>   key        scientificName   decimalLatitude decimalLongitude issues datasetKey #>   <chr>      <chr>                      <dbl>            <dbl> <chr>  <chr>      #> 1 2611167460 Murdannia macro…            11.5             103. cdc    50c9509d-… #> 2 2609083086 Bruguiera gymno…            11.5             103. cdc    50c9509d-… #> 3 2563487184 Cerbera manghas…            11.5             103. cdc    50c9509d-… #> 4 2563542656 Artocarpus hete…            13.4             104. cdc,c… 50c9509d-… #> 5 2609083379 Anacardium occi…            11.8             106. cdc,c… 50c9509d-… #> 6 2963951351 Calotropis giga…            11.7             105. cdc,c… 50c9509d-… #> # ℹ 94 more variables: publishingOrgKey <chr>, installationKey <chr>, #> #   hostingOrganizationKey <chr>, publishingCountry <chr>, protocol <chr>, #> #   lastCrawled <chr>, lastParsed <chr>, crawlId <int>, basisOfRecord <chr>, #> #   occurrenceStatus <chr>, taxonKey <int>, kingdomKey <int>, phylumKey <int>, #> #   classKey <int>, orderKey <int>, familyKey <int>, genusKey <int>, #> #   speciesKey <int>, acceptedTaxonKey <int>, acceptedScientificName <chr>, #> #   kingdom <chr>, phylum <chr>, order <chr>, family <chr>, genus <chr>, … # }
